div.head: On the text
div.p:
Hic considerandum est Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 1, n. 1 . This is distinction 15 which connects to the proceeding thus, for after the Master showed that the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father and the Son, now he inquires whether the Holy Spirit is able to give or send itself. And this is divided into three parts because he first shows that Holy Spirit sometimes sends itself, second he wishes to concludes this from the sending of the Son, third he asks whether we are now able to say that the Father has been sent. The second begins at
ne autem mireris Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 1, n. 5 . Third begins at
hic quaeritur, cur Pater Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 9, n. 1 .

The first part remains undivided, but the second is divided into two because in the first place he shows that the beginning o the mission of the Son is manifold, in the second place he says that varied mode of this same mission. The second begins at
hic quaeritur, tantum semel Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 6, n. 1 . And this is the division in general of the first part of this distinction.

Hic quaeritur utrum semel tantum Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 6, n. 1 . This is the second principal part of this distinction, where after the Master concludes the mission of the Holy spirit from the mission of the Son, now he inquires about the manifold mission of the Son and divides into two because in the first place the Master shows there is a diverse mode of the mission of the Son, in the second place the Master concludes that the Father is not nor was not sent. The second is at
hic quaeritur cur Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 9, n. 1 .

The first part stays undivided, but the second part is divided into two because in the first place the Master excludes every passive mission from the Father, in the second place regarding this is he recites one false opinion. The second begins at
ideoque putaverunt quidam haeretici Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 10
etc. And this is the division in general and the opinion of the present distinction about which is currently under consideration.

div.head: Question
div.p: Whether it ought to be admitted that any divine supposite is sent to any theologian; whether temporal mission of the Holy Spirit is a vital perception in the created mind; whether it is the case that the Holy Spirit is received from another and is in no way perceived by the one receiving it; whether it is the case that one receives the Holy Spirit and that same one having it in himself does not vitally perceive it.

div.head: Principal Arguments
div.p:
It is argued thus because to receive is purely passive and to perceive is active, therefore one is able to stand without the other. The consequence holds because with respect to the same terms the created mind is not able at the same time to be purely passive and active, since perceiving is not formally
passive, and also because the perceptive power is universally more perfect than a passive power.

In the second place, if the question were true, it would follows that be fitting for any divine person to be perceived by the same one by whom it would be proper to be sent. The consequent is false because it appropriate for the Father to be perceived, and nevertheless it is not fitting for him to be sent, as is clear
in the penultimate chapter of this distinction Lombardus, Sent., I, d. 15, c. 9 . The consequence is clear because, if the sending and the perception are the same, it follows that to be perceived and to be sent are the same.

In the third place, if the question were true, it would follows that anyone existing in grace would perceive evidently. The consequent is he is worthy by love or hate. And the consequence is clear because to perceive something is to know it. In the second place, it follows that the newly baptized would have a mental perception of grace or of the Holy Spirit. In the third place, it follows that someone would receive grace as intense as they perceive it. The consequent is false because then the virgin would have had a more intense perception than someone, indeed than any angel, because she received more grace than any angel.

In opposition are the words of the present distinction in chapter 10 where he says,
tunc unicuique Spiritus Sanctus mittitur cum a quocumque cognoscitur atque percipitur quantum cognosci et percipi potest secundum capacitatem animae rationalis Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 7, n. 2 . Again,
in the same distinction in chapter 12 Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 7, n. 2 ,
when to be sent is said to be perceived by the mind from time
Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, c. 20, n. 28 .

div.head: First conlusion
div.p: First conclusion: though the created intellective potency is in some way active with respect to some mission or vision of the divine, nevertheless no creature is able to be actively disposed, with respect to the expression of the uncreated word, through the mode of speaking. The first part is clear because in heaven the created intellective potency with respect to enjoyment is actively disposed. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is clear through the Decretals God bless our fruition stands or our formal beatitude consists in two acts of the because of the intellect and will which is the entire latitude of formal glory. The second part is clear because it follows that the uncreated Word would be a terminus produced from a created intellective power. The consequent is false, and the consequence is clear because it does not seem possible that the saying of anyone saying this is to speak a produced terminus of the same thing, and thus to speak would have a created uncreated terminus, which is false.

The first corollary: though the blessed soul is able to effectively concur with its own fruition, nevertheless it is not able to produce the light of glory in any mode. The first part is clear from the conclusion because such a light is producible by God alone.

The second corollary: though the created memory is able to be elevated beatifically through the divine essence as if an intellective species, nevertheless it is not the case that by this the uncreated Word is properly formed. This is clear because then the finite potency would produce an immeasurable term.
John of Marchia in his Determinations
Ripa, Determinationibus, Q. 3, a. 2, concl. 3
asserts the opposite of this corollary. The first part of is clear because God is able to supply two efficient causes in turn.

The third corollary: though the blessed soul is disposed passively with respect to fruition, nevertheless the same thing is able to be disposed actively with respect to cognition and delight. The first part is clear because it is receptive of these acts. The second part is clear through what is said in the conclusion and other corollaries.

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p:
Second conclusion: though it is appropriate only for the Holy Spirit and the Son to be sent, nevertheless active mission is proper to each divine person. The first part is clear because to be sent is not appropriate for the Father, but it is for the Son and Holy Spirit. The first part of the antecedent is from
Augustine IV De Trinitate, in the last chapter
who says that the Father
is not said to be sent Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, c. 20, n. 28 (PL 42:xxx) . The second part of the antecedent is clear through
Augustine II De Trinitate, chapter 5 saying
the Son was not able to be sent by the Father without the Holy Spirit, for the Father is understood as the one who sent him
because he was made the feminine because he certainly did not make him without the Holy Spirit
Augustinus, De Trinitate, II, c. 5, 8 (PL42:xxx) . But that the Holy Spirit was sent through the same one is clear through
Augustine in book IV De Trinitate, in chapter 19 , where he says expressly that
The Holy Spirit gives and sends itself Augustinus, XXX . Again John 15
I am sending you the spirit of truth Ioannes 15:26 . The second part is proved because the external work of the Trinity is undivided, but to send some person, etc., therefore. This is the argument of the
Master in distinction 15 Lombard, I, d. 15, XXX .

First corollary: it is not more repugnant for the Son to be sent by the Spirit that it is for the Son to be the spirator of the Holy Spirit. This is clear from what has been said because from each is true and not repugnant.
The second corollary: it ought to be admitted that it is appropriate for each person that the same thing is sent and sends itself. This is clear because to send is to act externally.

Third corollary: the perception of any divine person under a bodily species is not the passive mission of the same person. This is clear because the Father is not sent, and nevertheless appeared under a bodily likeness in the transfiguration when his voice was heard saying
Here is my beloved son Matthaeus 17:5; Lucas 15:24, Marcus 9:6 . From what has been said it is clear that to be sent is not merely absolute, but also convey a relation of some origin. This is clear because, if it were merely absolute, then it would be able to suit the Father, just as it suits the Son and the Holy Spirit. Whence
Augustine IV De Trinitate, in chapter 30
says,
that the Son is sent is to know that it is from another
Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, c. 20, n. 29 (PL 42:xx)

div.head: Tertia conclusio
div.p:
Third conclusion: though it is not the case that the Holy Spirit is received from something and that it is no way perceived by the one receiving it, nevertheless according to the common law non one is able to knowing perceive that he loves God meritoriously. The first part is clear because temporal sending of the Holy Spirit is a vital perception in the created mind, therefore. The antecedent is from the saying of Augustine introduced above in which it is said
the sending is said to be when the Holy Spirit is perceived by the mind from time Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, c. 20, n. 28 . The second part is clear through the saying of the
Apostle I Corinthians 13
Nothing is known to me, but I am not in this justified
I Corinthians 4:4 . Again
John, in chapter 3
The Spirit breathes where he wills but you will not know from where it comes or where he goes John 3:8
Again,
I do not know whether he is worthy of hate Ecclesiastes 9:1 , etc

The first corollary: while the law stand, though no one is able to know that they have ordinate love, nevertheless someone ought to believe that they have the sending of the Holy Spirit. The first is clear from what has been said. The second is proved because someone ought to believe that they have charity, therefore. The consequence holds because for the Holy Spirit to be sent into the mind is for charity to be infused in the mind, as the conclusion says. And the antecedent is clear from an adult approaching a sacrament by which grace is conferred, just as in the case of baptism and the eucharist.

The second corollary: it is not the case that the fruit of the divine mission increases in the mind and the vital perception of God is not intensified in the same thing. This is clear because, if not, if follows that not everyone receiving a sending of the divine person would have this vital perception, which is against the conclusion.

The third corollary: we do not always understand knowing uniformily. This is clear because otherwise one having such a perception would have evidence and experiential cognition, which is against what has been said. From what has been said the response is clear that it stands that some, etc.

div.head: Objections
div.p: Against the first conclusion, it follows that created memory would be able to concur through its own essential active power to the clarity of the light of glory. The consequent is false. The consequence is proved because created intelligence is no more able to concur to the supernatural disposition and vital union of the divine essence than to the light of glory.

In the second place against the first corollary, it is repugnant that the natural potency act supernaturally through its own essential power, therefore it is repugnant that the created intellect concur effectively for heavenly enjoyment

In the third place against the second corollary, created intelligence concurs effectively to the motion of vision by which the uncreated word is made present vitally to this intelligence. But this is to speak the uncreated word, therefore.

Against the third corollary,
it follows that beatitude corresponds more intensely, all things being equal, to what is more perfect in natural things, and as a consequence with equality of merits remaining the inequality of the first things will remain on account of the prior essential things, which is false. And the consequence is clear because because purer essential things are able to do more than less pure and imperfect things.

Against the second conclusion, to be sent and to send are correlative, therefore since being sent recognizes the relation of origin, it follows that to send speaks the same relation. But the Holy Spirit originates nothing internally, therefore it is not able to send any person. The consequence is clear because according to Augustine to be sent is to be originated, therefore to send is to originate

In the second place, because the relation which sending speaks either will be to that which is the mission, and then it will be common to three persons, and thus the Father will be sent. The consequence is clear because it is an external relation of reason. Or it speaks a relation to that which is sending, and if thus, therefore either it will be of reason only, and then it will be able to be in the Father, or real, and then again sending will not be essential, and as a consequence it will not be common to three persons, which is repugnant to the second part of this conclusion.
In the third place, to be sent speaks a relation of origin, therefore no person is able to send itself. The consequence is clear because non person is able to originate itself.

In the fourth place, to be sent speaks ann imperfection and indignity, therefore it not belong to any divine person. The consequence is valid, but the antecedent is proved because according
Dionysius in On the Angelic Hierarchy Dionysius, De angelica hierarchia, XXX
superior angels always assist God and not sent on account of their dignity. But the divine person has more dignity without proportion than every angel, therefore on account of its dignity it ought not be sent.

Against the third conclusion, someone is able to know that they are worthy of eternal life, therefore someone is able to know that they meritoriously love God, at least habitually. The consequence is valid, and the antecedent is proved because someone is able to know that they have filial fear, therefore also love. The consequence holds through
Gloss on the First John
perfect love cast out fear I John 4:18 . The antecedent is clear
Genesis 22
I know because you fear God Genesis 22:12 , that is I have made you to know. Item, Phillipians 2
let your requests be made known to God
Phil. 4:6 , where according to the
the Gloss XXX
this should not be understood as if they are made known to God who knew these things before they were, but that they are made known by us before God.

Again, anyone is able to know that he loves all things on account of God and has left all things behind, therefore he is able to know that he is worthy of eternal life. The consequence holds from Matthew 19
everyone that leaves etc. will posses eternal life Matthew 19:29

Again, someone is able to know that they have no servile fear, therefore he is able to know that he charity. The consequence holds
that passage from First John 4
perfect chartiy I John 4:18 , etc.

Against the first corollary, no article forces someone to believe that they are in charity, therefore. The antecedent is clear because, if there were, then the following would be given I believe in the Holy Catholic Church. But this is not because the Church in no place commands this, indeed it would seem to be hypocrisy to judge one self in charity, it even seems to be meritorious to judge one's self outside of charity, as is clear from the publican in
Luke 18 Luke 18:9-14 .

In the second place against the second corollary, the sinner ought expunged from sin, therefore he ought to believe that he is in charity. And further every adult either is in charity or outside, therefore everyone ought to believe that they are in charity, which is the first.
Against the other corollaries, every perception is some sort of cognition, and to the intension of perception it follows the intension of cognition, therefore these corollaries are false.

div.head: Responses
div.p: To the first, the consequence is denied, and it is said to the proof that not every sending of the divine person is a supernatural disposition as the argument intends to speak about disposition.
In the second place, the antecedent would be able to be denied generally.
In the third place, the consequence is able to be conceded which has already been negated, namely that memory, etc., indeed not by doing this in itself and about itself.

To the second, it is said that the antecedent is true, if through its natural power precisely it is not repugnant
to act in this manner with the addition of another potency. But in what is proposed it is not only the natural agent but also the supernatural agent that is elevating the potency of the natural power itself and actuating it for acting.
To the third, the minor is negated because to concur to such motion is not to speak the incarnate word.
To the fourth, it is said in the first place by denying the consequence because to the intension of a partial cause the effect of the action is not always intended.

In the second place, it would be able to be siad that retribution of the first things will not stand according to the proportion of merits because then no first thing would be give for baptismal grace, which is false.
In the third place, the consequent would be able to be conceded, nevertheless while concurring with the will of God, which is able to distribute rewards in whatever way pleases him.

To the first against the second conclusion, there is a distinction concerning the word to send, because in one mode it is understood principally authoritatively, in another mode consequently determinatively. In the first mode, it only applies to the Father and the Son, in the second mode to all three. Therefore, if the antecedent is taken in the first mode, then it is conceded. If it is taken in the second mode, then the consequence is denied and nor is the antecedent true.

To the second, it is said that to be sent speaks a relation not indeed to the one sending determinatively consequently, but principally authoritatively. Similarly it would be able to be said about sending that, if it were taken authoritatively, then no persona sends itself nor another unless that which it produces, but this nicely made clear in the second mode.

This is clear for the third argument,
about this see Thomas of Argentina Thomas de Argentina, XXX .

To the fourth, it is said that otherwise it is true in creatures because when a creature is sent, it is changed and moved to some place where was not previously. But because God is everywhere, therefore the divine person is able to be sent without mutation or imperfection because it is not sent where it was not, but in this manner was not a new effect, namely causing in the creature without change to itself, nevertheless not without change of the creature.

To the first against the third conclusion, the antecedent is denied, and to the proof it is replied by speaking about fear formed in charity. This is denied, and to the proof it should be said that Abraham knew from this divine revelation indicating this to himself, and to the other proof,
your petitions Phil. 4:6
etc., it is said that from the Gloss this is not had unless that in something we believe that we are from God from having heard and perhaps we know that the operated effect has come about. But from this, the opposition to the conclusion does not follow.
To another, the consequence is denied because he is not justified from works because Socrates despised reaches according to Jerome, and nevertheless he was not justified.
Again to another, the consequence is denied because from pure natural ability someone is able to have no fear.

To the first against the corollary, the antecedent is denied because it is contained under the aforenamed article or because this article speaks what is the same. Also the church says that concerning those receiving the sacrament of the eucharist, as is clear from Corinthians 2
but let man prove himself I Corinthians 11:28
etc. And this is able to occur without hypocrisy and boasting

To the third, the consequence is conceded as well as the consequent, and the further consequence is denied, but if follows well that he ought to be in such a state in which he believes that he is in charity, against the Monachus Niger.

To the fourth, the consequent would be able to be conceded regarding habitual cognition, but not actual, about which I speak in the conclusion and corollary. Again, it would be possible to be said that such cognition is intensified, nevertheless not in the being of cognition, but only in the being of experiential perception. This is clear from what has been said.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Hic considerandum est Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 1, n. 1 . This distinction contains seven conclusions. The first: that the Holy Spirit is God and gift, and therefore he gives and is given. He gives inasmuch as he is God, and is given inasmuch as he is gift, and as such he is not less than the Father or the Son.

The second conclusion: if the Holy Spirit were not able to give himself, then the Father and the Son would be able to give something which the Holy Spirit is not able to give and Father and the Son would do something which the Holy Spirit is not able to do, which is inconvenient because external work of the Trinity
is undivided. Therefore it follows that the Holy Spirit proceeds temporally, is sent, and is given from itself.

Third conclusion: that the Father is never read as having been sent, but only the Son and the Holy Spirit. But the Son is sent by the Father and himself and by the Holy Spirit, and this sending was the incarnation which was a common work in three persons.

The fourth conclusion: that when the Son says in John 8
I have not come from myself John 7:28 , this was said according to the form of a servant but the incarnation was not done according to this form, but rather according to the form of God.

Fifth conclusion: The Son of God is further being eternally generated, on account of which he is said to be sent, but according to which he is better and more truly said to be begotten. He is said to be sent in two ways, either because he appeared visibly in the world in the flesh, or because moves himself invisibly into pious souls, as is perceived and known by them. In the first mode, he was sent a single time. In the second mode, he is sent every day, not with the result that he is a man, but that he is with man.

Sixth conclusion: though the Father is known from time, just as the Son, nevertheless he is not said to be sent because in the Father is the authority of the principle because he is the principle of the Son and the Holy Spirit, and he does not have a that from which he is.

Seventh conclusion: The Father is not therefore said to have sent the Son and the Holy Spirit because, just some heretics think, he is greater and they are lesser, but on account of an authority of suitable principle and because the Father did not appear in a visible creature, as the Son and Holy Spirit did, because he appeared only in a voice, which is not something visible, but only audible, etc.
